Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is safely monitoring in real-time the condition of any surface that is affected by unwanted ice accumulation. Instead of using a time consuming and potentially dangerous visual inspection process, building and structure owners and operators can remotely assess icing conditions on any surface where ice could accumulate. Adopting this time and cost saving technology reduces the risk of the public and workers being harmed by falling ice, and also assists managers in making the appropriate operating decisions for icing mitigation measures such as activation of a deicing system. Initial applications may include bridges, tall buildings, bus terminals, museums and other structures.

This I-Corps project is a water phase sensor that determines the icing condition at a point on the surface of structure. When a structure goes through an icing cycle (ice accumulation, ice persistence and ice shedding), water changes phase from liquid to solid and back. When ice accumulates, water freezes on the surface which can be detected by the sensor. Before the ice sheds, water starts to appear beneath the ice layer. The sensor can also identify this water. This technology is the only point source surface mounted ice detector, and thus is distinguished from other technologies that do not attach on a surface and that utilize the weather conditions in the local area to predict the presence of ice on a surface. In addition, the other detection technologies utilize materials that are different from the material of the structure's surface. For these reasons, existing sensors may not provide a good representation of ice collecting on the actual surface of the structure. This sensor's accuracy, reliability, and durability have been demonstrated through laboratory and field tests. This testing includes three years of deployment in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A surface mounted water phase-state sensor has been developed to determine the medium that covers the sensors, i.e., water, ice, or air. The sensor utilizes the variation of the electrical conductivity between different media which include the same medium, i.e., water, in different phases. This process is done by measuring the output voltage and the temperature from the location where the sensor is installed. The sensor is flat, compact, rigid, easy to install on a surface, and can be mounted in a variety of ways on various structures. Since the sensor can also be used to detect water, it can recognize when the ice melts on the interface between the ice layer and the structure?s surface. The sensor went through numerous laboratory and field examinations which confirmed the sensor?s reliability, durability, and excellent functionality. Considering the uniqueness of the sensor and its function, we believed that our sensor has a wide range of applications for any system that requires detecting the presence of ice.

We found out that our sensor has multiple customer segments that we planned to explore. Considering how general the customer segments (companies, buildings, etc.) were, our I-Corps instructors directed us to focus on only one customer segment to explore. We selected the automotive industry due to its high volume production and our technical mentor?s area of expertise. 

Several questions arose prior to and during the customer discovery that required answers: (1) who are the direct customers,(2) what are the value propositions, and (3) who are the decision makers. Throughout the program, we interviewed more than 100 individuals with different roles (i.e., engineers, managers, technicians, and marketing) from different entities with various levels in automotive industries that includes Tier 2, Tier 1, OEM, and after market. Based on our customer discovery, we found out that our sensor is an important tool in lowering the temperature of evaporator which would help in reducing the time to comfort by approximately 50%. Additionally, it can also contribute in reducing the size of the system by one pound which will decrease the vehicle cost by $5-7 per system e. Moreover, from our discussion with the purchasing, planning, and engineering manager in OEMS and Tier 1, we found that OEMs (Vehicle manufacturer) are the decision makers for the sensor, while Tier 1 are the direct customers.

Through this journey, we understood the goal of our I-Corps instructors who suggested to only focusing on one customer segment, as all these details would have not been known if it was explored at the same time while exploring other customer segments.

Several conclusions can be drawn from the exploration that we conducted, which also lead to our final decision. It takes 5 to 7 years for a new technology to be implemented in vehicles due to all the testing and production requirements, in addition to the dynamic nature of designs in automotive industry. Also, we learned that we have targeted a highly commoditized product space. Significant resource and infrastructure costs will be charged prior to receiving any incoming revenue. Moreover, there are many requirements that need to be fulfilled to be a supplier in automotive industry, which include financial strength, stability, and certification. I recall a statement from one of the interviewees in which he said, ?Going to automotive industry is like climbing Everest?, which we indeed learned during the customer discovery. Therefore, our final decision was a NO-GO due to the aforementioned reasons. Nevertheless, this was not the end of the road for us. Instead, it actually encouraged us to consider about different paths that we have started after finishing the program.

I-Corps program gave us an initial experience in how to explore new market and to decide if our technology is a product market fit. To discover this as early as possible is very important in order to save time and money instead of spending on a business that has a high probability of failing. Utilizing our gained experience, we tried to explore different markets. We are in contact with a sensor company that shows a great interest in using our sensor as part of their anti/de-icing system. Also, a contact has been established with bridges to use our sensor as a part of de-icing system. Overall, our contacts and sharing experiences have convinced us of the importance of our sensor in being a part of the anti/de-icing system on structures.
